question: What is another name for the Spring ligament?
short_explanation: The Spring ligament is also known as the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament.
long_explanation: The plantar calcaneonavicular ligament, commonly called the Spring ligament, connects the sustentaculum tali of the calcaneus to the navicular bone and helps support the medial longitudinal arch.
clinical_application: Spring ligament dysfunction may contribute to medial arch collapse, which massage therapy can address through arch support and tissue release.
source_reference: Trail Guide to the Body, 6th Edition

question: What is another name for the Short plantar ligament?
short_explanation: The Short plantar ligament is also known as the plantar calcaneocuboid ligament.
long_explanation: The plantar calcaneocuboid ligament, or Short plantar ligament, connects the calcaneus to the cuboid and provides stability to the lateral longitudinal arch.
clinical_application: Dysfunction of the Short plantar ligament may contribute to cuboid syndrome and lateral foot instability.

question: Which ligament directly supports the head of the talus?
short_explanation: The Spring ligament supports the head of the talus.
long_explanation: The Spring ligament supports the talar head and helps prevent medial arch collapse by connecting the calcaneus to the navicular.
clinical_application: Weakness in the Spring ligament can lead to flatfoot deformity, which massage therapy may help manage with supportive techniques.
source_reference: Trail Guide to the Body, 6th Edition

question: Which ligament primarily supports the lateral longitudinal arch?
short_explanation: The Short plantar ligament supports the lateral longitudinal arch.
long_explanation: The Short plantar ligament stabilizes the calcaneocuboid joint and supports the lateral longitudinal arch of the foot.
clinical_application: Lateral foot pain and instability may stem from dysfunction in the Short plantar ligament.

question: Damage to which ligament is more likely to cause medial arch collapse?
short_explanation: Spring ligament damage often results in medial arch collapse.
long_explanation: Because it supports the talar head and medial longitudinal arch, the Spring ligament plays a key role in maintaining medial foot height. Damage can lead to flatfoot.
clinical_application: Manual therapy for medial arch dysfunction should assess Spring ligament integrity and associated compensatory patterns.
source_reference: Trail Guide to the Body, 6th Edition

question: Which bone does the Short plantar ligament attach to anteriorly?
short_explanation: The Short plantar ligament attaches anteriorly to the cuboid.
long_explanation: The Short plantar ligament spans from the calcaneus to the cuboid bone, helping to stabilize the lateral side of the foot.
clinical_application: Cuboid syndrome can be linked to dysfunction of the Short plantar ligament.

question: The Spring ligament connects the calcaneus to which bone?
short_explanation: The Spring ligament connects the calcaneus to the navicular.
long_explanation: The Spring ligament spans from the sustentaculum tali of the calcaneus to the navicular bone and helps support the medial arch.
clinical_application: Palpation of the Spring ligament area can aid in identifying medial foot dysfunction.
source_reference: Trail Guide to the Body, 6th Edition

question: Which ligament is more directly involved in cuboid syndrome?
short_explanation: The Short plantar ligament supports the calcaneocuboid joint and can be involved in cuboid syndrome.
long_explanation: Cuboid syndrome often involves dysfunction of the calcaneocuboid joint and its stabilizers, including the Short plantar ligament.
clinical_application: Targeted manual therapy to the Short plantar ligament can help relieve symptoms of cuboid syndrome.

question: Where would you palpate to assess the Spring ligament?
short_explanation: The Spring ligament lies inferior to the medial malleolus along the medial foot.
long_explanation: The Spring ligament can be palpated along the medial foot below the medial malleolus, where it supports the medial arch.
clinical_application: Spring ligament palpation can help identify arch dysfunction or injury contributing to foot mechanics issues.
source_reference: Trail Guide to the Body, 6th Edition

correctAnswer: Anterior to the calcaneus on the lateral foot
question: Where would you palpate to assess the Short plantar ligament?
options: Anterior to the calcaneus on the lateral foot
short_explanation: The Short plantar ligament lies anterior to the calcaneus on the lateral side of the foot.
long_explanation: The Short plantar ligament can be palpated on the lateral foot, where it connects the calcaneus to the cuboid and stabilizes the lateral arch.
clinical_application: Manual therapists can palpate the Short plantar ligament to assess for tenderness or restriction contributing to lateral foot dysfunction.
